turn.text: And then why did -- but why don't you determine the truth of the matter and why -- and you know that it is true and why -- what -- what's the statement that the -- then prosecute him?

turn.speaker: jack_pf_gremillion
turn.label: Mr. Jack P.F. Gremillion
turn.text: Because he had violated the law.
We --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: There was a largely (Voice Overlap) on constitutional grounds to me and then --

turn.speaker: jack_pf_gremillion
turn.label: Mr. Jack P.F. Gremillion
turn.text: I was ordered to do this by these particular judges.
And then that was -- of that great of importance.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Why did you say that?

turn.speaker: jack_pf_gremillion
turn.label: Mr. Jack P.F. Gremillion
turn.text: What's that?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What did I understand you to say?

turn.speaker: jack_pf_gremillion
turn.label: Mr. Jack P.F. Gremillion
turn.text: The judges met en banc and ask me by order, would I file this Bill of Information, because they were anxious to find out their racketeering influences themselves.
This was a very hidden controversy in -- in Louisiana, in the City of New Orleans.
And somebody had to do something about it.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Incidentally Mr. Attorney General, have all these other prosecutions under the facts that you've mentioned?
Have there been constitutions with statements about other public officials, you mentioned one --

turn.speaker: jack_pf_gremillion
turn.label: Mr. Jack P.F. Gremillion
turn.text: The ladies -- Lambert case was a statement that the District Attorney had put a guy in the penitentiary, put a prison into penitentiary on --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: That's what he thought of.

turn.speaker: jack_pf_gremillion
turn.label: Mr. Jack P.F. Gremillion
turn.text: That he illegally committed to the penitentiary on urgent testimony of a certain prison.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And what -- and these other prosecutions, they also were -- were statements about public officials?

turn.speaker: jack_pf_gremillion
turn.label: Mr. Jack P.F. Gremillion
turn.text: They were affirmed, yes by our Supreme Court.
In other --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well in the -- then he thought in the state court and you have to do this in order to avoid the truth to proceed.

turn.speaker: jack_pf_gremillion
turn.label: Mr. Jack P.F. Gremillion
turn.text: Yes.
Now -- now let me -- in this Lambert case, the District Attorney was defamed and we have a procedure.
Well, if the District Attorney is interested, he's got to refuse himself at the court -- a request to the court and that is if he's interested in the prosecution, do you understand?
And the only person that can prosecute -- the court has got to find an attorney within the district who has the capabilities of a District Attorney.
And then if he can't find any, he certifies that to the Attorney General.
And the Attorney General can assign another District Attorney to prosecute that particular case.
Or I could go in and prosecute it myself because I have that authority.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: General, I noticed that the gist of this complaint is that there is vice, and crime, and corruption on Bourbon Street in New Orleans.
Is there any proof in -- is there any proof of the fact that there is no such vice or corruption on Bourbon Street or--?

turn.speaker: jack_pf_gremillion
turn.label: Mr. Jack P.F. Gremillion
turn.text: Oh, no.
No, I don't -- I don't make that contention Your Honor.
I'm -- I'm sure that a place like Bourbon Street that there is a lot of vice there.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Okay, but you -- just a moment, do you say they allow vice there?

turn.speaker: jack_pf_gremillion
turn.label: Mr. Jack P.F. Gremillion
turn.text: No, I didn't say that.
I say I -- I presumed that there is, I assume that there is because there has been several suits that the District Attorney filed, that he padlocked some of the places.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: But who -- who would -- you presumed that they would let it.
Who would do that?
The police who were -- who were assigned to him and that these judges --

turn.speaker: jack_pf_gremillion
turn.label: Mr. Jack P.F. Gremillion
turn.text: Somebody --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- must experience only, it must be his only investigators?

turn.speaker: jack_pf_gremillion
turn.label: Mr. Jack P.F. Gremillion
turn.text: Somebody would evidently be lax somewhere along the line.
But you see he -- he claims in his statement that the judges --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: But would you have any -- would you have any jurisdiction over that?

turn.speaker: jack_pf_gremillion
turn.label: Mr. Jack P.F. Gremillion
turn.text: No, I don't think so.
That would be up to the District Attorney or it would be up to the police department.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I thought you could still foresee that anyone in -- in the event could --

turn.speaker: jack_pf_gremillion
turn.label: Mr. Jack P.F. Gremillion
turn.text: Oh, I could go in there but I don't make it a practice to run around in the State of Louisiana superseding District Attorneys and so forth unless they're actually involved -- or involved and the situation is of such gravity that it necessitates it such as the case here.
But you see he claims that the judges blocked his investigations and we proved on the trial of this case that the judges did not, that that was false, that they wanted to cooperate with him.
And if they did cooperate with him, that they approved motions for expenses, and that he had 12 policemen that could do -- go do undercover work if he wanted, and so forth.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: The policemen are the ones who -- who have the responsibility of policing Bourbon Street, do they not?

turn.speaker: jack_pf_gremillion
turn.label: Mr. Jack P.F. Gremillion
turn.text: Well, there's no doubt about that, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: There is no doubt about that.

turn.speaker: jack_pf_gremillion
turn.label: Mr. Jack P.F. Gremillion
turn.text: No doubt about that.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Would they -- if there was this vice and corruption there, would they be likely on assignment to him to clean that place up?

turn.speaker: jack_pf_gremillion
turn.label: Mr. Jack P.F. Gremillion
turn.text: Well, I assume that they would be -- yes that would be the logic between them.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Even though as you say you assume that they permitted the vice to continue there.

turn.speaker: jack_pf_gremillion
turn.label: Mr. Jack P.F. Gremillion
turn.text: With that assumption, yes, I agree.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: They don't seem to fit with the --

turn.speaker: jack_pf_gremillion
turn.label: Mr. Jack P.F. Gremillion
turn.text: Well, I can't change the facts, Your Honor.
I mean –-

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: We can't tell you the fact that there was vice and corruption?

turn.speaker: jack_pf_gremillion
turn.label: Mr. Jack P.F. Gremillion
turn.text: I said in my opinion -- I said in my opinion, I assume that there was.
And because of the fact that the District Attorney has filed padlock proceedings on several places and has actually close some of them.
I'm trying to be as frank and truthful as I possibly can.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, he sets here that no, there was -- we -- we have -- there's no question raised about expenditures until the first beer drinking joint began to cave in.

turn.speaker: jack_pf_gremillion
turn.label: Mr. Jack P.F. Gremillion
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: That's his -- that's his complaint.

turn.speaker: jack_pf_gremillion
turn.label: Mr. Jack P.F. Gremillion
turn.text: Yes but he didn't prove that.
He didn't prove that the judges stopped his -- his so-called funds until that happened.
That was absolutely repudiated by the testimony of the judges.

That's the very point I'm coming to, that this thing was so grave and that there was -- that this particular charge would really amount into bribery by racketeers of the judges that something had to be done about it.
The truth had to come out.
And that was proved to be deliberately false by the testimony.
There's no evidence in here to show that that was even -- that he even thought that.
He'd had a reasonable belief of that.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: One of the judges called you and to audit you to prosecute him.

turn.speaker: jack_pf_gremillion
turn.label: Mr. Jack P.F. Gremillion
turn.text: I didn't have to do it.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You didn't have to do that.

turn.speaker: jack_pf_gremillion
turn.label: Mr. Jack P.F. Gremillion
turn.text: I had that discretion under Article 7, Section 56.
But as I told this Court --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: They would have the same time to get to you that they're reasonably charged with.
They had the right to use the Attorney General to investigate Bourbon Street.

turn.speaker: jack_pf_gremillion
turn.label: Mr. Jack P.F. Gremillion
turn.text: No, they did not.
No one ever ask me to do that.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- what they wanted you to do --

turn.speaker: jack_pf_gremillion
turn.label: Mr. Jack P.F. Gremillion
turn.text: Now frankly -- frankly it sets about superseding the District Attorney.
In the case of Kemp versus Stanley, our Supreme Court held that the Attorney General could not supersede a District Attorney who is willing to do his duty.
And so here Mr. Garrison has been working hard and has been closing up quite a few places.
So I would have no actual authority to supersede him unless he had actually refused to do his duty, do you understand?

turn.speaker: jack_pf_gremillion
turn.label: Mr. Jack P.F. Gremillion
turn.text: But --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, he has not refused to do his duty in that connection?

turn.speaker: jack_pf_gremillion
turn.label: Mr. Jack P.F. Gremillion
turn.text: No, not that I know of.
But he claimed that the judges had kept him from doing this.
And that was absolutely false because as I said previously, time and time again, the record shows that he had clear funds available.
The record shows that he had these 12 policemen to do his work.
And that the judges in no way had ever issued any messages to him or any orders to him to stop his crime prevention work.
I thank you.
Anymore questions?

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: No, I think none, General.

turn.speaker: eberhard_p_deutsch
turn.label: Mr. Eberhard P. Deutsch
turn.text: Thank you.
I may have just (Voice Overlap)

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: eberhard_p_deutsch
turn.label: Mr. Eberhard P. Deutsch
turn.text: Just a few more moments, I think I can answer your question, Mr. Chief Justice on the record.
In the first place in the supplemental brief, a question was just asked a few moments ago for the second time.
In the supplemental brief of the State of Louisiana on page 9, a short paragraph of the second full paragraph on that page.
Prior to October 1962, expenditures from the fund for vice investigations by appellant's office had been approved by individual judges.
They had been approved.
Now, page 376 of the record, one of the judges has questioned on the subject with regard to prior administrations of District Attorneys.

Let me ask you, this judge, “if you don't feel the District Attorney has the discretion, can you point to any single case in the previous District Attorney's administration that you refuse to authorize, meaning as you'll find in the context, these orders were investigation funds?”
And the answer is “No, I don't remember any.”
So that they were always approved up to this time as appellant said when the beer drinking joints have began to get closed or --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: How long had this man been elected?

turn.speaker: eberhard_p_deutsch
turn.label: Mr. Eberhard P. Deutsch
turn.text: About five months I think, yes.
He was -- took office in May and this happened in --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: The record --

turn.speaker: eberhard_p_deutsch
turn.label: Mr. Eberhard P. Deutsch
turn.text: -- statement was made in November of the record.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Did the record show whether he ran on a platform of doing this which he says he was trying to do it?

turn.speaker: eberhard_p_deutsch
turn.label: Mr. Eberhard P. Deutsch
turn.text: I think the Attorney General made that statement.
There isn't any question and after all, it's almost a matter of public record of which I believe you could take judicial notice if it's not in there.
In so many words, he ran independently.
He had no political party.
There isn't any statement there that he said the judges were an association of armed robbers.
He says, “I have no organization.
My opponents are the association of armed robbers.”
He wasn't talking about the judges.
That's -- a string that that language won't take --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Who was he talking about?

turn.speaker: eberhard_p_deutsch
turn.label: Mr. Eberhard P. Deutsch
turn.text: Pardon?

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Who was he talking about?

turn.speaker: eberhard_p_deutsch
turn.label: Mr. Eberhard P. Deutsch
turn.text: The political organizations which had opposed him in his elect.
I have no organization.
I have no -- he says that.
That's expressed on opponent, I think.
My opponents are the association of armed robbers, meaning the professional political organizations which had opposed him in his election.
He was elected --

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: Well I --

turn.speaker: eberhard_p_deutsch
turn.label: Mr. Eberhard P. Deutsch
turn.text: Pardon?

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: He had the --

turn.speaker: eberhard_p_deutsch
turn.label: Mr. Eberhard P. Deutsch
turn.text: What maybe the opin --?

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: Well I -- are the association of armed robbers.

turn.speaker: eberhard_p_deutsch
turn.label: Mr. Eberhard P. Deutsch
turn.text: I think -- well, I didn't have it performed but here the sentence before that says, “I have no organization --

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: It turned to them.

turn.speaker: eberhard_p_deutsch
turn.label: Mr. Eberhard P. Deutsch
turn.text: That's -- and that follows right with it.
“I have no organization, the other officials are the association of armed robbers.”

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Do you think that statement was what the people used they called to proceed but they won't admit it at least that they were bad people and he was a good man.

turn.speaker: eberhard_p_deutsch
turn.label: Mr. Eberhard P. Deutsch
turn.text: Well, I don't think there's any question you could ask and he would answer that question affirmatively.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Deutsch, -- Mr. Deutsch, how long was he in office before this judge attacked him for --

turn.speaker: eberhard_p_deutsch
turn.label: Mr. Eberhard P. Deutsch
turn.text: For, well --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- for suggesting the calendar?

turn.speaker: eberhard_p_deutsch
turn.label: Mr. Eberhard P. Deutsch
turn.text: He took office in May.
This controversy started three or four months later, I think.
I suppose I can get it.
The statement which is the subject of this -- once the subject of this prosecution was made on November 2nd, published on November 2nd as I recall it.

Now, there had been a building up of the controversy and statements back and forth when the retired judge made his statement charging appellant with responsibility for the backlog of these cases, that wasn't the first thing that was said on this subject that had been going back and forth.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Very well.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Do you think it's a -- is there any difference whether this statement, they maybe run and attacked upon these judges in their official rather than their personal character?

turn.speaker: eberhard_p_deutsch
turn.label: Mr. Eberhard P. Deutsch
turn.text: Well, I think the judgment must go with me in either event but I do think it makes that difference because it brings it under the scope of what we have called sedition in the last 175 or 100 maybe year.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: You say that it attacked upon them solely and exclusively in their official capacity?

turn.speaker: eberhard_p_deutsch
turn.label: Mr. Eberhard P. Deutsch
turn.text: Would -- would make it sedition in the -- shall I say appropriate sense.
I don't know whether it was an offense for him to make the statement as to what he thought this Court would ultimately do in this case.
I certainly had my very strong views and I ask you to support it.

turn.speaker: jack_pf_gremillion
turn.label: Mr. Jack P.F. Gremillion
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, may I ask you one thing?

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes, General.

turn.speaker: jack_pf_gremillion
turn.label: Mr. Jack P.F. Gremillion
turn.text: What he -- what Mr. Deutsch is just saying about the organizations, that's his interpretation of it but he, the District Attorney, never did explained that and there's nothing in the record to show that he was talking about a political organization.
So I don't know what he was talking about but I do know that he was in a controversy with these judges and that's when -- that was a subject matter of his speech at that particular auditorium.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes, very well.
